name: Newbie questions: getting to level 40 and help with a build

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
The OC will take you to ~ 20.  We have a lvl 20 build section on the ecb.

If you are planning on doing connecting adventures, Sou and HotU are somewhat connected.  I believe there is a custom Mod for inbetween.

HotU I believe will take you into the 30s, but I don't think you will get to lvl 40.

But you, my friend, are in luck!

Because NWN is neverending story!  There are literally thousands of Mods, available for free, on the NWVault!  And there are adventures there that will take you all the way to lvl 40.

I think eye of the beholder does.

Of course, you may prefer more fun with others and more challenge than SP can offer - and that is when NWN opens itself to the wonderful worlds of Online Persistent fun!  Also, free of charge.

So, enjoy, no matter what you do.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
I can heartily recommend the Aielund Saga, which will get you to level 36-7. But be aware, there's no Dev Crit there.

Swordflight is great, and I believe you can currently get into the 30s - Rogue Knight is still constructing the final part - but by the time it's done, you'll certainly hit 40.

I don't know if these two are available to you, but if you want to reach level 40 you can either follow the OC with Mines of Twin Summit (designed to begin at level 16-ish, so you can just jump straight in after the OC), or do SoU and HotU and port your character into Sands of Fate (designed for a level c28 character, and going all the way to 40).

If you want to know more about any of these - and others - have a look in our Modules forum, where they all are expanded on and blathered about.

Equally, we have a PW section, where some of the more popular ones are given some leg-room. Special mention, however, must - and should - be given to the wonderful World of Greyhawk. The gods know, it ain't easy, so be warned. But if you decide to give it a whirl, do sign up to our sister site: WoG, which is full of useful stuff and is an excellent community (including some of our own Guild members).

Enjoy yourself!

Cheers

posts.author: Dingpot
posts.content:
Just to answer the OP as I recently purchased Daggerfell, Moonsea and PotSC when they were on very special offer at GOG.com, like less than £1 each!

Daggerfell starts at level 7 I think and if you use a level 1 toon you have the option to manually level up or have the module do it for you. You will finish around level 15 if you do all the side quests which is the starting level for Moonsea, and indeed Daggerfell is referenced occasionally in the plot but they both work as stand alones. I actually played Moonsea first using Mick Dagger's  Guardian of Light but at levelled to 15 and equipped with the stuff you have at the end of OC. It was terribly overpowered and combat a little too easy throughout. My advice would be to level up manually in the module and take what you are given. You will find plenty of good stuff as you go and should finish the module around level 25. For Daggerfell I used Valerfor's excellent Dwarven Warmaster with no special equipment. Again combat was mostly on the easy side. Both are excellent stories however and I will definitely go back and play them again, possibly even with a caster build if Stagmeister will ever forgive me!

PotSC was a bit of a different beast with more puzzles and thinking which is not really my cup of tea, ymmv. Cant remember the starting level but it was quite low and ended up around level 13 iirc. Probably won't play this one much, I thought the final battle was disproportionately hard, not impossible but it kind of caught me by surprise compared to the rest of the mod.

Hopefully some food for thought there, and I would agree with everything above about the custom mods - Aielund is my personal favourite but I play many others as well.
